org.gearvrf.animation

Class GVRAnimation

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.animation.GVRAnimation
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    GVRKeyFrameAnimation, GVRMaterialAnimation, GVRPostEffectAnimation, GVRTransformAnimation

    public abstract class GVRAnimation
extends java.lang.Object
    The root of the GVRF animation tree. This class (and the engine) supply the common functionality: descendants are tiny classes that contain compiled (ie, no runtime reflection is used) code to change individual properties. Most animations involve a scene object's position, a scene object's surface appearance, or an optional "post effect": accordingly, most actual animations descend from GVRTransformAnimation, GVRMaterialAnimation, or GVRPostEffectAnimation and not directly from GVRAnimation.

    All animations have at least three or more required parameters: the object to animate, the duration, and any animation parameters. In many cases, there are overloaded methods to specify the animation parameters in convenient ways: for example, you can specify a color as an Android Color or as a float[3] of GL-compatible 0 to 1 values. In addition, all the stock animations that animate a type like, say, GVRMaterial 'know how' to find the GVRMaterial inside a GVRSceneObject.

    This means that most animations have two or four overloaded constructors. This is trouble for the animation developer - who must keep four sets of JavaDoc in sync - but probably clear enough for the animation user. However, there are also four optional parameters: the interpolator, the repeat type, the repeat count, and an on-finished callback. Adding these to an overload tree would, well, overload both developers and users!

    Thus, animations use a sort of Builder Pattern: you set the optional parameters via set() methods that return this, so you can chain them like 

     
 new GVRScaleAnimation(sceneObject, 1.5f, 2f) //
         .setRepeatMode(GVRRepetitionType.PINGPONG) //
         .start(animationEngine);
    which will 'pulse' the size of the sceneObject from its current level to double size, and back.

    Animations run in a GVRDrawFrameListener, so they happen before your GVRMain.onStep() handler, which happens before GVRF renders the scene graph. This has two consequences:

    • When you start an animation in an GVRMain.onStep() handler, it starts running on the next frame.
    • If you start multiple animations (with the same duration and the same interpolator!) in the same onStep() handler, they will always be in sync. That is, you can 'compose' animations simply by starting them together; you do not need to write a composite animation that animates multiple properties in a single method.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_REPEAT_COUNT

        public static final int DEFAULT_REPEAT_COUNT
        The default repeat count only applies to the two repeat modes, not to the default run-once mode. The default repeat count is 2, so that a ping pong animation will return to the start state, even if you don't setRepeatCount(2).
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • GVRAnimation

        protected GVRAnimation(GVRHybridObject target,
                       float duration)
        Base constructor. Sets required fields, initializes optional fields to default values.
        Parameters:
        target - The object to animate. Note that this constructor makes a private copy of the target parameter: It is up to descendant classes to cast the target to the expected type and save the typed value.
        duration - The animation duration, in seconds.

    • Method Detail

      • checkTarget

        protected static java.lang.Class<?> checkTarget(GVRHybridObject target,
                                                java.lang.Class<?>... supported)
        Many animations can take multiple target types: for example, material animations can work directly with GVRMaterial targets, but also 'know how' to get a GVRMaterial from a GVRSceneObject. They can, of course, just expose multiple constructors, but that makes for a combinatorial explosion when the other parameters also 'want' to be overloaded. This method allows them to just take a GVRHybridObject and throw an exception if they get a type they can't handle; it also returns the matched type (which may not be equal to target.getClass()) so that calling code doesn't have to do instanceof tests.
        Parameters:
        target - A GVRHybridObject instance
        supported - An array of supported types
        Returns:
        The element of supported that matched
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If target is not an instance of any of the supported types

      • setInterpolator

        public GVRAnimation setInterpolator(GVRInterpolator interpolator)
        Set the interpolator. By default, animations proceed linearly: at X percent of the duration, the animated property will be at X percent of the way from the start state to the stop state. Specifying an explicit interpolator lets the animation do other things, like accelerate and decelerate, overshoot, bounce, and so on.
        Parameters:
        interpolator - An interpolator instance. null gives you the default, linear animation.
        Returns:
        this, so you can chain setProperty() calls.

      • setRepeatMode

        public GVRAnimation setRepeatMode(int repeatMode)
        Set the repeat type. In the default run-once mode, animations run once, ignoring the repeat count. In ping pong and repeated modes, animations do honor the repeat count, which defaults to 2.
        Parameters:
        repeatMode - One of the GVRRepeatMode constants
        Returns:
        this, so you can chain setProperty() calls.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If repetitionType is not one of the GVRRepeatMode constants

      • setRepeatCount

        public GVRAnimation setRepeatCount(int repeatCount)
        Set the repeat count.
        Parameters:
        repeatCount -
        A negative number Means the animation will repeat indefinitely. See the notes on stopping an animation.
        0 After start(), 0 means 'stop at the end' and schedules a clean shutdown. Calling setRepeatCount(0) before start() is really pointless and silly ... but start() is special-cased so setting the repeat count to 0 will do what you expect.
        A positive number Specifies a repeat count
        Returns:
        this, so you can chain setProperty() calls.

      • setOnFinish

        public GVRAnimation setOnFinish(GVROnFinish callback)
        Set the on-finish callback. The basic GVROnFinish callback will notify you when the animation runs to completion. This is a good time to do things like removing now-invisible objects from the scene graph.

        The extended GVROnRepeat callback will be called after every iteration of an indefinite (repeat count less than 0) animation, giving you a way to stop the animation when it's not longer appropriate.

        Parameters:
        callback - A GVROnFinish or GVROnRepeat implementation.

        Note: Supplying a GVROnRepeat callback will set the repeat count to a negative number. Calling setRepeatCount(int) with a non-negative value after setting a GVROnRepeat callback will effectively convert the callback to a GVROnFinish.

        Returns:
        this, so you can chain setProperty() calls.

      • start

        public GVRAnimation start(GVRAnimationEngine engine)
        Start the animation. Changing properties once the animation is running can have unpredictable results.
        Parameters:
        engine - animation engine to start.

        This method is exactly equivalent to GVRAnimationEngine.start(GVRAnimation) and is provided as a convenience so you can write code like 

         
 GVRAnimation animation = new GVRAnimationDescendant(target, duration)
         .setOnFinish(callback).start(animationEngine);
        instead of 
         
 GVRAnimation animation = new GVRAnimationDescendant(target, duration)
         .setOnFinish(callback);
 animationEngine.start(animation);
        Returns:
        this, so you can save the instance at the end of a chain of calls

      • isFinished

        public final boolean isFinished()
        Checks whether the animation has run to completion. For run-once animations, this means only that the animation has timed-out: generally, this means that the (optional) onFinish callback has been invoked and the animation 'unregistered' by the animation engine but it's not impossible that there is some lag between time-out and finalization.

        For repeated or ping pong animations, this method can tell you whether an animation is on its first iteration or one of the repetitions. If you need to, you can terminate a repetitive animation 'abruptly' by calling GVRAnimationEngine.stop(GVRAnimation) or 'cleanly' by calling setRepeatCount(0). Do note that both these approaches are sort of 'legacy' - the clean way to handle indeterminate animations is to use setOnFinish(GVROnFinish) to set an GVROnRepeat handler, before calling start(GVRAnimationEngine).

        Returns:
        true if done or repeating; false if on first run.

      • reset

        public void reset()

      • getRepeatCount

        public int getRepeatCount()
        Get the current repeat count. A negative number means the animation will repeat indefinitely; zero means the animation will stop after the current cycle; a positive number is the number of cycles after the current cycle.
        Returns:
        The current repeat count

      • getDuration

        public float getDuration()
        The duration passed to the constructor. This may be useful if you have to, say, 'undo' a running animation.
        Returns:
        The duration passed to the constructor.

      • getElapsedTime

        public float getElapsedTime()
        How long the animation has been running. This may be useful if you have to, say, 'undo' a running animation. With repeated animations, this may be longer than the duration.
        Returns:
        How long the animation has been running.

      • animate

        protected abstract void animate(GVRHybridObject target,
                                float ratio)
        Override this to create a new animation. Generally, you do this by changing some property of the mTarget, and letting GVRF handle screen updates automatically.
        Parameters:
        target - The GVRF object to animate
        ratio - The start state is 0; the stop state is 1.
